metadata.case_name: Appellants (Reversioners of Wadhawa Singh) v. Respondent (Daughter of Wadhawa Singh)

facts.text: Property in dispute belonged to Wadhawa Singh, father of the respondent.
Wadhawa Singh died in the year 1933.
After Wadhawa Singh's death, his widow succeeded to the estate and made a gift of the property in favour of her daughter, the respondent, in April 1933.
Appellants, as reversioners to the estate of Wadhawa Singh, filed a suit questioning the 1933 gift. The suit was decreed and the decree confirmed on appeal. The respondent was a party to that suit.
Hindu Succession Act came into force on 17-6-1956.
After coming into force of the Hindu Succession Act, the widow made a second gift of the same lands to the respondent.
Appellants filed suit for possession of the lands alleging that the second gift was void.
Trial Court decreed the appellants' suit.
On appeal, respondent succeeded in the first Appellate Court and the High Court on second appeal. High Court judgment dated 18th May, 1967 in P.A. No. 158 of 1967.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the widow had right to make the second gift after Hindu Succession Act, given the first gift was invalidated and she was not in possession.
Whether Section 14 of Hindu Succession Act applies to make widow full owner, absent possession.
Whether succession to husband's estate upon widow's death in 1963 is governed by Section 8 of Hindu Succession Act or pre-Act law, given husband died in 1933.
Effect of Punjab customary law excluding daughter from ancestral property in preference to reversioners.

petitioner_arguments.text: Widow had no right to make gift in 1933, decree binds respondent. Post-HSA second gift invalid as widow not in possession, so not full owner under S.14.
Eramma v. Verrupanna holds S.8 not retrospective; old Hindu Law applies on widow's death. Under Punjab custom, daughter not entitled to ancestral property over reversioners.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Eramma v. Verrupanna (1966) 2 SCR 626; Rattigan's Digest of Customary Law para 23

respondent_arguments.text: Second gift valid; upon widow's death after HSA, daughter succeeds in preference to reversioners under S.8 as per Punjab High Court views.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu Succession Act S.8; Banso v. Charan Singh AIR 1961 Punjab 45; Kuldip Singh v. Karnail Singh AIR 1961 Punjab 573

court_reasoning.text: First gift decree binds; widow not in possession post-decree, so S.14 does not apply to make her full owner; second gift ineffective.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unless limited owner in possession, S.14 does not apply.

court_reasoning.text: Succession opens on death of limited owner (widow); governed by law then in force (S.8 HSA), as if last male holder died then. Distinguishes Eramma as not considering this contingency.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Material point of time is death of widow when succession opens.

court_reasoning.text: Follows Privy Council: widow holds estate of inheritance to herself and heirs of husband; reversioners have mere spes successionis. S.8 not retrospective but prospective from opening of succession.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words 'dying intestate' in S.8 describe status, not time; contrast S.6.

court_reasoning.text: Legal fiction of last male dying on limited owner's death requires applying then-current law; Punjab custom overridden by HSA.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Previous decree res judicata; no circumstances shown for daughter under custom.

holdings.text: Second gift void as widow not full owner under S.14 due to lack of possession.
On widow's death, succession to husband's estate under S.8 HSA; daughter entitled in preference to reversioners.
Punjab custom does not apply post-HSA; previous decision res judicata.

precedents_cited.relevance: Daughter succeeds on widow's death post-HSA under S.8
Next heir determined by law on widow's death date
Held old law governs; court disagrees
Similar view to Mysore but not directly on point
S.8 not apply where S.14 applicable due to possession
S.8 not retrospective; but did not consider succession on limited owner's death
Widow's estate anomalous; succession opens on her death to husband's heirs as if he died then
Reversioners have spes successionis; law on widow's death governs

precedents_cited.case_name: Mahant Salig Ram v. Musammat Maya Devi
precedents_cited.relevance: Rattigan's Digest authoritative on Punjab custom
Correctness of Rattigan para 23 not disputed

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Succession Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: S.14 requires possession for full ownership; S.8 governs succession opening on widow's death; not retrospective

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Law of Inheritance (Amendment) Act, 1929
statutes_cited.relevance: Interpreted similarly; law on limited owner's death applies

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act, 1937
statutes_cited.relevance: Widow in possession becomes full owner under S.14 HSA

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, holding that while the second gift was void, succession to Wadhawa Singh's estate opened on widow's death in 1963 under S.8 HSA, entitling daughter (respondent) over reversioners; Punjab custom inapplicable.
outcome.relief_granted: Respondent retains property as heir under S.8

key_quotes.text: The succession does not open to the heirs of the husband until the termination of the widows estate. Upon the termination of that estate the property descends to those who would have been the heirs at the husband if he had lived up to and died at the moment of her death.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle from Privy Council adopted for S.8 application

key_quotes.text: If you are bidden to treat an imaginary state of affairs as real, you must surely... also imagine as real the consequences... The statute says that you must imagine a certain state of affairs it does not say that having done so, you must cause or permit your imagination to boggle.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies applying current law to fictional death date

key_quotes.text: The material point of time being the date when the succession opens, namely, the death of the widow.
key_quotes.speaker: court
